bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Henry Hanson, April 12, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] requests information on the history of yellow fever in Peru. [Carter] comments on working relations with the Peruvian government.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Henry Hanson, April 12, 1922
div1.opener:
Dr H. B.
Hanson
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
April 12, 1922.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p:
I would be glad if you can give me any points in the history of
yellow fever in Peru or on the West Coast generally. I have notes
from Beranger: Feraud: Hirsh and Greisinger of its occurrence in the
/50s and again in the latter /60s and early /70s. I have not the books
with me.

One epidemic is reported to have had dengue as a fore-runner--pre-
paring the way for it.

Mrs. Gorgas has a letter from Aileen from which I judge that you
have accepted the place of Jefe de Salubridad. If Peruvians were dif-
ferent, you might do a good work there--making it you life work.
Meigs made work in Peru his life work and he did well, but I have no
idea what you could accomplish, Peru and Peruvians being as they are.
It would be well if you see Pezet--the Ambassador to the U. S.--who
must be in Lima now. He is an able man--French rather than Peruvian in
his outlook.

With very best remembrances to each one of you, in which Laura,
who is writing this, joins.
